name: add
desc: Assumes a pattern of numbers. Adds the given number to each item in the pattern.

name: sub
desc: Like add, but the given numbers are subtracted.
examples:
n("0 2 4".sub("<0 1 2 3>")).scale("C4:minor")
// See add for more information.

name: mul
desc: Multiplies each number by the given factor.

name: div
desc: Divides each number by the given factor.

name: round
desc:
Assumes a numerical pattern. Returns a new pattern with all values rounded
to the nearest integer.

name: floor
desc:
Assumes a numerical pattern. Returns a new pattern with all values set to
their mathematical floor. E.g. 3.7 replaced with to 3, and -4.2
replaced with -5.

name: ceil
desc:
Assumes a numerical pattern. Returns a new pattern with all values set to
their mathematical ceiling. E.g. 3.2 replaced with 4, and -4.2
replaced with -4.

name: toBipolar
desc:
Assumes a numerical pattern, containing unipolar values in the range 0 ..

Returns a new pattern with values scaled to the bipolar range -1 .. 1

name: fromBipolar
desc:
Assumes a numerical pattern, containing bipolar values in the range -1 .. 1
Returns a new pattern with values scaled to the unipolar range 0 .. 1

name: range
desc:
Assumes a numerical pattern, containing unipolar values in the range 0 .. 1.
Returns a new pattern with values scaled to the given min/max range.
Most useful in combination with continuous patterns.

name: rangex
desc:
Assumes a numerical pattern, containing unipolar values in the range 0 .. 1
Returns a new pattern with values scaled to the given min/max range,
following an exponential curve.

name: range2
desc:
Assumes a numerical pattern, containing bipolar values in the range -1 .. 1
Returns a new pattern with values scaled to the given min/max range.

name: ratio
desc:
Allows dividing numbers via list notation using ":".
Returns a new pattern with just numbers.

name: useRNG
desc:
Sets which random number generator to use. Historically Strudel would
use useRNG('legacy'), which remains the default. To use a new more statistically
precise RNG, try useRNG('precise').

name: withSeed
desc: Modify a pattern by applying a function to the randomSeed control if present

params.name: func
params.description: Function from seed (or undefined) to seed (or undefined)

name: seed
desc:
Change the seed for random signals. Normally, random signals depend on time,
so two patterns at the same time will have the same random values. Specifying
a new seed changes the signal output by rand. This also affects other functions
that use randomness, like shuffle and sometimes.

params.name: n
params.description: A new seed. Can be any number.

examples:
$: s("hh*4").degrade();
$: s("bd*4").degrade().seed(1); // Will degrade different events from the hi-hat

name: scrub
desc:
Allows you to scrub an audio file like a tape loop by passing values that represents the position in the audio file
in the optional array syntax ex: "0.5:2", the second value controls the speed of playback

name: euclid
desc:
Changes the structure of the pattern to form an Euclidean rhythm.
Euclidean rhythms are rhythms obtained using the greatest common
divisor of two numbers.  They were described in 2004 by Godfried
Toussaint, a Canadian computer scientist.  Euclidean rhythms are
really useful for computer/algorithmic music because they can
describe a large number of rhythms with a couple of numbers.

params.name: steps
params.description: the number of steps to fill

name: euclidRot
desc: Like euclid, but has an additional parameter for 'rotating' the resulting sequence.

params.name: steps
params.description: the number of steps to fill

examples:
// A Samba rhythm necklace from Brazil
note("c3").euclidRot(3,16,14)

name: euclidLegato
desc:
Similar to euclid, but each pulse is held until the next pulse,
so there will be no gaps.

params.name: steps
params.description: the number of steps to fill

name: euclidLegatoRot
desc:
Similar to euclid, but each pulse is held until the next pulse,
so there will be no gaps, and has an additional parameter for 'rotating'
the resulting sequence

params.name: steps
params.description: the number of steps to fill

name: euclidish
desc:
A 'euclid' variant with an additional parameter that morphs the resulting
rhythm from 0 (no morphing) to 1 (completely 'even'). For example
sound("bd").euclidish(3,8,0) would be the same as
sound("bd").euclid(3,8), and sound("bd").euclidish(3,8,1) would be the
same as sound("bd bd bd"). sound("bd").euclidish(3,8,0.5) would have a
groove somewhere between.
Inspired by the work of Malcom Braff.

params.name: steps
params.description: the number of steps to fill

params.name: groove
params.description: exists between the extremes of 0 (straight euclidian) and 1 (straight pulse)

name: withValue
desc:
Returns a new pattern, with the function applied to the value of
each hap. It has the alias fmap.

params.name: func
params.description: to to apply to the value

name: appWhole
desc:
Assumes 'this' is a pattern of functions, and given a function to
resolve wholes, applies a given pattern of values to that
pattern of functions.

name: appBoth
desc:
When this method is called on a pattern of functions, it matches its haps
with those in the given pattern of values.  A new pattern is returned, with
each matching value applied to the corresponding function.
In this _appBoth variant, where timespans of the function and value haps
are not the same but do intersect, the resulting hap has a timespan of the
intersection. This applies to both the part and the whole timespan.

name: appLeft
desc:
As with appBoth, but the whole timespan is not the intersection,
but the timespan from the function of patterns that this method is called
on. In practice, this means that the pattern structure, including onsets,
are preserved from the pattern of functions (often referred to as the left
hand or inner pattern).

name: appRight
desc:
As with appLeft, but whole timespans are instead taken from the
pattern of values, i.e. structure is preserved from the right hand/outer
pattern.

name: into
desc:
Breaks a pattern into pieces according to the structure of a given pattern.
True values in the given pattern cause the corresponding subcycle of the
source pattern to be looped, and for an (optional) given function to be
applied. False values result in the corresponding part of the source pattern
to be played unchanged.

name: arpWith
desc: Selects indices in in stacked notes.

name: arp
desc: Selects indices in in stacked notes.

name: struct
desc: Applies the given structure to the pattern:
examples:
note("c,eb,g")
  .struct("x ~ x ~ ~ x ~ x ~ ~ ~ x ~ x ~ ~")
  .slow(2)

name: mask
desc: Returns silence when mask is 0 or "~"

name: reset
desc: Resets the pattern to the start of the cycle for each onset of the reset pattern.

name: restart
desc:
Restarts the pattern for each onset of the restart pattern.
While reset will only reset the current cycle, restart will start from cycle 0.

name: sequenceP
desc: Takes a list of patterns, and returns a pattern of lists.

name: stack
desc: The given items are played at the same time at the same length.

name: register
desc: Registers a new pattern method. The method is added to the Pattern class + the standalone function is returned from register.

params.name: name
params.description: name of the function, or an array of names to be used as synonyms

params.name: func
params.description: function with 1 or more params, where last is the current pattern

params.name: patternify
params.description:
defaults to true; if set to false, you will have more control over the arguments to func as they will be
in their raw form and it will be up to you to patternify them and/or query them for values

name: compress
desc: Compress each cycle into the given timespan, leaving a gap
examples:
cat(
  s("bd sd").compress(.25,.75),
  s("~ bd sd ~")
)

name: fastGap
desc: speeds up a pattern like fast, but rather than it playing multiple times as fast would it instead leaves a gap in the remaining space of the cycle. For example, the following will play the sound pattern "bd sn" only once but compressed into the first half of the cycle, i.e. twice as fast.

name: focus
desc: Similar to compress, but doesn't leave gaps, and the 'focus' can be bigger than a cycle

name: ply
desc: The ply function repeats each event the given number of times.

name: fast
desc: Speed up a pattern by the given factor. Used by "*" in mini notation.
examples: s("bd hh sd hh").fast(2) // s("[bd hh sd hh]*2")

name: hurry
desc: Both speeds up the pattern (like 'fast') and the sample playback (like 'speed').

name: slow
desc: Slow down a pattern over the given number of cycles. Like the "/" operator in mini notation.
examples: s("bd hh sd hh").slow(2) // s("[bd hh sd hh]/2")

name: inside
desc: Carries out an operation 'inside' a cycle.

name: outside
desc: Carries out an operation 'outside' a cycle.

name: lastOf
desc: Applies the given function every n cycles, starting from the last cycle.

name: firstOf
desc: Applies the given function every n cycles, starting from the first cycle.

name: every
desc: An alias for firstOf

name: early
desc: Nudge a pattern to start earlier in time. Equivalent of Tidal's <~ operator

params.name: cycles
params.description: number of cycles to nudge left

name: late
desc: Nudge a pattern to start later in time. Equivalent of Tidal's ~> operator

params.name: cycles
params.description: number of cycles to nudge right

name: zoom
desc: Plays a portion of a pattern, specified by the beginning and end of a time span. The new resulting pattern is played over the time period of the original pattern:
examples:
s("bd*2 hh*3 [sd bd]*2 perc").zoom(0.25, 0.75)
// s("hh*3 [sd bd]*2") // equivalent

name: bite
desc:
Splits a pattern into the given number of slices, and plays them according to a pattern of slice numbers.
Similar to slice, but slices up patterns rather than sound samples.

name: linger
desc: Selects the given fraction of the pattern and repeats that part to fill the remainder of the cycle.

name: segment
desc: Samples the pattern at a rate of n events per cycle. Useful for turning a continuous pattern into a discrete one.

name: swingBy
desc: The function swingBy x n breaks each cycle into n slices, and then delays events in the second half of each slice by the amount x, which is relative to the size of the (half) slice. So if x is 0 it does nothing, 0.5 delays for half the note duration, and 1 will wrap around to doing nothing again. The end result is a shuffle or swing-like rhythm

name: swing
desc: Shorthand for swingBy with 1/3:

name: invert
desc: Swaps 1s and 0s in a binary pattern.

name: when
desc: Applies the given function whenever the given pattern is in a true state.

name: off
desc: Superimposes the function result on top of the original pattern, delayed by the given time.

name: brak
desc:
Returns a new pattern where every other cycle is played once, twice as
fast, and offset in time by one quarter of a cycle. Creates a kind of
breakbeat feel.

name: rev
desc: Reverse all cycles in a pattern. See also revv for reversing a whole pattern.

name: revv
desc: Reverse a whole pattern. See also rev for reversing each cycle.

name: pressBy
desc:
Like press, but allows you to specify the amount by which each
event is shifted. pressBy(0.5) is the same as press, while
pressBy(1/3) shifts each event by a third of its timespan.

name: press
desc: Syncopates a rhythm, by shifting each event halfway into its timespan.

name: hush
desc: Silences a pattern.

name: palindrome
desc: Applies rev to a pattern every other cycle, so that the pattern alternates between forwards and backwards.

name: juxBy
desc: Jux with adjustable stereo width. 0 = mono, 1 = full stereo.
examples: s("bd lt [~ ht] mt cp ~ bd hh").juxBy("<0 .5 1>/2", rev)

name: jux
desc: The jux function creates strange stereo effects, by applying a function to a pattern, but only in the right-hand channel.
examples: s("bd lt [~ ht] mt cp ~ bd hh").jux(rev)
s("bd lt [~ ht] mt cp ~ bd hh").jux(press)
s("bd lt [~ ht] mt cp ~ bd hh").jux(iter(4))

name: echoWith
desc: Superimpose and offset multiple times, applying the given function each time.

params.name: func
params.description: function to apply, given the pattern and the iteration index

name: echo
desc: Superimpose and offset multiple times, gradually decreasing the velocity

name: stut
desc: Deprecated. Like echo, but the last 2 parameters are flipped.

name: plyWith
desc: The plyWith function repeats each event the given number of times, applying the given function to each event.\n

params.name: func
params.description: function to apply, given the pattern

name: plyForEach
desc:
The plyForEach function repeats each event the given number of times, applying the given function to each event.
This version of ply uses the iteration index as an argument to the function, similar to echoWith.

params.name: func
params.description: function to apply, given the pattern and the iteration index

name: iter
desc: Divides a pattern into a given number of subdivisions, plays the subdivisions in order, but increments the starting subdivision each cycle. The pattern wraps to the first subdivision after the last subdivision is played.

name: iterBack
desc: Like iter, but plays the subdivisions in reverse order. Known as iter' in tidalcycles

name: repeatCycles
desc: Repeats each cycle the given number of times.

name: chunk
desc: Divides a pattern into a given number of parts, then cycles through those parts in turn, applying the given function to each part in turn (one part per cycle).

name: chunkBack
desc: Like chunk, but cycles through the parts in reverse order. Known as chunk' in tidalcycles

name: fastChunk
desc:
Like chunk, but the cycles of the source pattern aren't repeated
for each set of chunks.

name: chunkInto
desc: Like chunk, but the function is applied to a looped subcycle of the source pattern.
examples:
sound("bd sd ht lt bd - cp lt").chunkInto(4, hurry(2))
  .bank("tr909")

name: chunkBackInto
desc: Like chunkInto, but moves backwards through the chunks.
examples:
sound("bd sd ht lt bd - cp lt").chunkInto(4, hurry(2))
  .bank("tr909")

name: ribbon
desc:
Loops the pattern inside an offset for cycles.
If you think of the entire span of time in cycles as a ribbon, you can cut a single piece and loop it.

params.name: offset
params.description: start point of loop in cycles

name: tag
desc: Tags each Hap with an identifier. Good for filtering. The function populates Hap.context.tags (Array).
examples:
s("saw!16").note("F1")
  .lpf(tri.range(40, 80).slow(4)).lpenv(5).lpq(4).lpd(0.15)
  .when(rand.late(0.1).gte(0.5), x => x.transpose("12").tag('altered'))
  .when(rand.late(0.2).gte(0.5), x => x.s("square").tag('altered'))
  .when("<0 1>", x => x.filter((hap) => hap.hasTag('altered')))

name: filter
desc: Filters haps using the given function

name: filterWhen
desc: Filters haps by their begin time

name: within
desc: Use within to apply a function to only a part of a pattern.

params.name: end
params.description: end within cycle (0 - 1). Must be > start

params.name: func
params.description: function to be applied to the sub-pattern

name: pace
desc:
Experimental
Speeds a pattern up or down, to fit to the given number of steps per cycle.
examples:
sound("bd sd cp").pace(4)
// The same as sound("{bd sd cp}%4") or sound("<bd sd cp>*4")

name: polymeter
desc:
Experimental
Aligns the steps of the patterns, creating polymeters. The patterns are repeated until they all fit the cycle. For example, in the below the first pattern is repeated twice, and the second is repeated three times, to fit the lowest common multiple of six steps.
examples:
// The same as note("{c eb g, c2 g2}%6")
polymeter("c eb g", "c2 g2").note()

name: stepcat
desc:
'Concatenates' patterns like fastcat, but proportional to a number of steps per cycle.
The steps can either be inferred from the pattern, or provided as a [length, pattern] pair.
Has the alias timecat.
examples:
stepcat("bd sd cp","hh hh").sound()
// the same as "bd sd cp hh hh".sound()

name: stepalt
desc:
Experimental
Concatenates patterns stepwise, according to an inferred 'steps per cycle'.
Similar to stepcat, but if an argument is a list, the whole pattern will alternate between the elements in the list.
examples:
stepalt(["bd cp", "mt"], "bd").sound()
// The same as "bd cp bd mt bd".sound()

name: take
desc:
Experimental
Takes the given number of steps from a pattern (dropping the rest).
A positive number will take steps from the start of a pattern, and a negative number from the end.
examples:
"bd cp ht mt".take("2").sound()
// The same as "bd cp".sound()

"bd cp ht mt".take("1 2 3").sound()
// The same as "bd bd cp bd cp ht".sound()

"bd cp ht mt".take("-1 -2 -3").sound()
// The same as "mt ht mt cp ht mt".sound()

name: drop
desc:
Experimental
Drops the given number of steps from a pattern.
A positive number will drop steps from the start of a pattern, and a negative number from the end.

name: extend
desc:
Experimental
extend is similar to fast in that it increases its density, but it also increases the step count
accordingly. So stepcat("a b".extend(2), "c d") would be the same as "a b a b c d", whereas
stepcat("a b".fast(2), "c d") would be the same as "[a b] [a b] c d".
examples:
stepcat(
  sound("bd bd - cp").extend(2),
  sound("bd - sd -")
).pace(8)

name: replicate
desc:
Experimental
replicate is similar to fast in that it increases its density, but it also increases the step count
accordingly. So stepcat("a b".replicate(2), "c d") would be the same as "a b a b c d", whereas
stepcat("a b".fast(2), "c d") would be the same as "[a b] [a b] c d".
TODO: find out how this function differs from extend
examples:
stepcat(
  sound("bd bd - cp").replicate(2),
  sound("bd - sd -")
).pace(8)

name: expand
desc:
Experimental
Expands the step size of the pattern by the given factor.

name: contract
desc:
Experimental
Contracts the step size of the pattern by the given factor. See also expand.

name: shrink
desc:
Experimental
Progressively shrinks the pattern by 'n' steps until there's nothing left, or if a second value is given (using mininotation list syntax with :),
that number of times.
A positive number will progressively drop steps from the start of a pattern, and a negative number from the end.

name: grow
desc:
Experimental
Progressively grows the pattern by 'n' steps until the full pattern is played, or if a second value is given (using mininotation list syntax with :),
that number of times.
A positive number will progressively grow steps from the start of a pattern, and a negative number from the end.

name: tour
desc:
Experimental
Inserts a pattern into a list of patterns. On the first repetition it will be inserted at the end of the list, then moved backwards through the list
on successive repetitions. The patterns are added together stepwise, with all repetitions taking place over a single cycle. Using pace to set the
number of steps per cycle is therefore usually recommended.
examples:
"[c g]".tour("e f", "e f g", "g f e c").note()
   .sound("folkharp")
   .pace(8)

name: zip
desc:
Experimental
'zips' together the steps of the provided patterns. This can create a long repetition, taking place over a single, dense cycle.
Using pace to set the number of steps per cycle is therefore usually recommended.
examples:
zip("e f", "e f g", "g [f e] a f4 c").note()
   .sound("folkharp")
   .pace(8)

name: chop
desc:
Cuts each sample into the given number of parts, allowing you to explore a technique known as 'granular synthesis'.
It turns a pattern of samples into a pattern of parts of samples.
examples:
samples({ rhodes: 'https://cdn.freesound.org/previews/132/132051_316502-lq.mp3' })
s("rhodes")
 .chop(4)
 .rev() // reverse order of chops
 .loopAt(2) // fit sample into 2 cycles

name: striate
desc: Cuts each sample into the given number of parts, triggering progressive portions of each sample at each loop.

name: loopAt
desc: Makes the sample fit the given number of cycles by changing the speed.

name: slice
desc:
Chops samples into the given number of slices, triggering those slices with a given pattern of slice numbers.
Instead of a number, it also accepts a list of numbers from 0 to 1 to slice at specific points.

name: splice
desc: Works the same as slice, but changes the playback speed of each slice to match the duration of its step.

name: fit
desc:
Makes the sample fit its event duration. Good for rhythmical loops like drum breaks.
Similar to loopAt.

name: loopAtCps
desc:
Makes the sample fit the given number of cycles and cps value, by
changing the speed. deprecated: use loopAt or fit instead, together with setCps / setCpm.

name: beat
desc:
creates a structure pattern from divisions of a cycle
especially useful for creating rhythms

name: morph
desc:
Takes two binary rhythms represented as lists of 1s and 0s, and a number
between 0 and 1 that morphs between them. The two lists should contain the same
number of true values.

name: shuffle
desc:
Slices a pattern into the given number of parts, then plays those parts in random order.
Each part will be played exactly once per cycle.

name: scramble
desc:
Slices a pattern into the given number of parts, then plays those parts at random. Similar to shuffle,
but parts might be played more than once, or not at all, per cycle.

name: chooseWith
desc:
Choose from the list of values (or patterns of values) using the given
pattern of numbers, which should be in the range of 0..1

name: chooseInWith
desc:
As with {chooseWith}, but the structure comes from the chosen values, rather
than the pattern you're using to choose with.

name: choose
desc:
Chooses from the given list of values (or patterns of values), according
to the pattern that the method is called on. The pattern should be in
the range 0 .. 1.

name: choose2
desc:
As with choose, but the pattern that this method is called on should be
in the range -1 .. 1

name: chooseCycles
desc: Picks one of the elements at random each cycle.

name: wchoose
desc: Chooses randomly from the given list of elements by giving a probability to each element

name: wchooseCycles
desc: Picks one of the elements at random each cycle by giving a probability to each element
examples: wchooseCycles(["c c c",5], ["a a a",3], ["f f f",1]).fast(4).note()

// The probability can itself be a pattern
wchooseCycles(["bd(3,8)","<5 0>"], ["hh hh hh",3]).fast(4).s()

name: degradeBy
desc:
Randomly removes events from the pattern by a given amount.
0 = 0% chance of removal
1 = 100% chance of removal

name: degrade
desc: Randomly removes 50% of events from the pattern. Shorthand for .degradeBy(0.5)

name: undegradeBy
desc:
Inverse of degradeBy: Randomly removes events from the pattern by a given amount.
0 = 100% chance of removal
1 = 0% chance of removal
Events that would be removed by degradeBy are let through by undegradeBy and vice versa (see second example).

name: undegrade
desc:
Inverse of degrade: Randomly removes 50% of events from the pattern. Shorthand for .undegradeBy(0.5)
Events that would be removed by degrade are let through by undegrade and vice versa (see second example).

name: sometimesBy
desc:
Randomly applies the given function by the given probability.
Similar to someCyclesBy

name: sometimes
desc: Applies the given function with a 50% chance

name: someCyclesBy
desc:
Randomly applies the given function by the given probability on a cycle by cycle basis.
Similar to sometimesBy

name: someCycles
desc: Shorthand for .someCyclesBy(0.5, fn)

name: often
desc: Shorthand for .sometimesBy(0.75, fn)

name: rarely
desc: Shorthand for .sometimesBy(0.25, fn)

name: almostNever
desc: Shorthand for .sometimesBy(0.1, fn)

name: almostAlways
desc: Shorthand for .sometimesBy(0.9, fn)

name: never
desc: Shorthand for .sometimesBy(0, fn) (never calls fn)

name: always
desc: Shorthand for .sometimesBy(1, fn) (always calls fn)

name: cyclesPer
desc:
A pattern measuring the duration of events,
in cycles per event. cyclesPer doesn't have structure itself, but takes structure, and therefore
event durations, from the pattern that it is combined with.
For example cyclesPer.struct("1 1 [1 1] 1") would give the same as "0.25 0.25 [0.125 0.125] 0.25".
See also its reciprocal, per, also known as perCycle.
examples:
sound("bd sd [bd bd] sd*4 [- sd] [bd [bd bd]]")
  .note(cyclesPer.add(20))

name: per
desc:
A pattern measuring the 'shortness' of events, or in other words, the duration of pattern events,
in events per cycle. per doesn't have structure itself, but takes structure, and therefore
event durations, from the pattern that it is combined with.
For example per.struct("1 1 [1 1] 1") would give the same as "4 4 [8 8] 4".
See also its reciprocal, cyclesPer.

name: perx
desc:
Like per but measures the shortness of events according to an exponential curve. In
particular, where the event duration halves, the
returned value increases by one. perx.struct("1 1 [1 [1 1]] 1") would therefore be
the same as "3 3 [4 [5 5]] 3".

name: as
desc: Sets properties in a batch.

params.name: mapping
params.description: the control names that are set

name: layer
desc: Layers the result of the given function(s). Like superimpose, but without the original pattern:

name: superimpose
desc: Superimposes the result of the given function(s) on top of the original pattern:

name: setDefaultJoin
desc:
Sets the default method of combining events from two patterns (aka alignment) in Strudel.
The default method is 'in', meaning that patterns to the left will (typically) dictate the event timings when combined with patterns to the right.
By changing alignment to 'out', the opposite will happen. With 'mix', they will combine their event timings.
Note that we say the default method, because alignments can also be set explicitly with calls like
'add.mix', 'set.squeeze', etc.

params.name: method
params.description: Default join method to use. Options: 'in', 'out', 'mix', 'squeeze', 'squeezeout', 'reset', 'restart', 'poly'

examples:
setDefaultJoin('mix') // also try 'in', 'out', 'squeeze', etc.
s("saw").vel("1 0.5").note("F A C E").delay("0 0.2 0.3")

name: slowcat
desc: Concatenation: combines a list of patterns, switching between them successively, one per cycle.

name: slowcatPrime
desc: Concatenation: combines a list of patterns, switching between them successively, one per cycle. Unlike slowcat, this version will skip cycles.

name: cat
desc: The given items are concatenated, where each one takes one cycle.

name: arrange
desc:
Allows to arrange multiple patterns together over multiple cycles.
Takes a variable number of arrays with two elements specifying the number of cycles and the pattern to use.

name: seqPLoop
desc:
Similarly to arrange, allows you to arrange multiple patterns together over multiple cycles.
Unlike arrange, you specify a start and stop time for each pattern rather than duration, which
means that patterns can overlap.

name: sequence
desc: See fastcat

name: seq
desc: Like cat, but the items are crammed into one cycle.

name: apply
desc: Applies the given function to the pattern. Like layer, but with a single function:

name: parray
desc: Turns a list of patterns into a single pattern which outputs list-values

name: pick
desc:
Picks patterns (or plain values) either from a list (by index) or a lookup table (by name).
Similar to inhabit, but maintains the structure of the original patterns.
examples: note("<0 1 2!2 3>".pick(["g a", "e f", "f g f g" , "g c d"]))

name: pickmod
desc:
The same as pick, but if you pick a number greater than the size of the list,
it wraps around, rather than sticking at the maximum value.
For example, if you pick the fifth pattern of a list of three, you'll get the
second one.

name: pickF
desc: pickF lets you use a pattern of numbers to pick which function to apply to another pattern.

params.name: lookup
params.description: a pattern of indices or names

params.name: lookup
params.description: the array or lookup object of functions from which to pull

examples:
note("<c2 d2>(3,8)").s("square")
.pickF("<jr l> f", { jr:jux(rev), f:fast(2), l:x=>x.lpf(800) })

name: pickmodF
desc:
The same as pickF, but if you pick a number greater than the size of the functions list,
it wraps around, rather than sticking at the maximum value.

params.name: lookup
params.description: a pattern of indices or names

params.name: lookup
params.description: the array or lookup object of functions from which to pull

name: pickOut
desc: Similar to pick, but it applies an outerJoin instead of an innerJoin.

name: pickmodOut
desc:
The same as pickOut, but if you pick a number greater than the size of the list,
it wraps around, rather than sticking at the maximum value.

name: pickRestart
desc: Similar to pick, but the choosen pattern is restarted when its index is triggered.

name: pickmodRestart
desc:
The same as pickRestart, but if you pick a number greater than the size of the list,
it wraps around, rather than sticking at the maximum value.

name: pickReset
desc: Similar to pick, but the choosen pattern is reset when its index is triggered.

name: pickmodReset
desc:
The same as pickReset, but if you pick a number greater than the size of the list,
it wraps around, rather than sticking at the maximum value.

name: inhabit
desc:
Picks patterns (or plain values) either from a list (by index) or a lookup table (by name).
Similar to pick, but cycles are squeezed into the target ('inhabited') pattern.

name: inhabitmod
desc:
The same as inhabit, but if you pick a number greater than the size of the list,
it wraps around, rather than sticking at the maximum value.
For example, if you pick the fifth pattern of a list of three, you'll get the
second one.

name: squeeze
desc:
Pick from the list of values (or patterns of values) via the index using the given
pattern of integers. The selected pattern will be compressed to fit the duration of the selecting event
examples: note(squeeze("<0@2 [1!2] 2>", ["g a", "f g f g" , "g a c d"]))

name: all
desc:
Applies a function to all the running patterns. Note that the patterns are groups together into a single stack before the function is applied. This is probably what you want, but see each for
a version that applies the function to each pattern separately.
$: sound("bd - cp sd")
$: sound("hh*8")
all(fast("<2 3>"))

$: sound("bd - cp sd")
$: sound("hh*8")
all(x => x.pianoroll())

name: each
desc:
Applies a function to each of the running patterns separately. This is intended for future use with upcoming 'stepwise' features. See all for a version that applies the function to all the patterns stacked together into a single pattern.
$: sound("bd - cp sd")
$: sound("hh*8")
each(fast("<2 3>"))

name: n
desc:
Selects the given index:

for samples, it picks the sample by index, with wrap around
for scales, it picks the scale degree
for voicings, it picks the voice index

name: note
desc:
Plays the given note name or midi number. A note name consists of

a letter (a-g or A-G)
optional accidentals (b or #)
optional (possibly negative) octave number (0-9). Defaults to 3

Examples of valid note names: c, bb, Bb, f#, c3, A4, Eb2, c#5
You can also use midi numbers instead of note names, where 69 is mapped to A4 440Hz in 12EDO.

name: chord
desc: The chord to voice

params.name: symbols
params.description: chord symbols to voice e.g., C, Eb, Fm7, G7. The symbols can be defined via addVoicings

examples: chord("<Am C D F Am E Am E>").voicing()

name: dictionary
desc: Which dictionary to use for the voicings. This falls back to the default dictionary if not provided

params.name: dictionaryName
params.description: which dictionary (having been defined with addVoicings) to use

examples:
addVoicings('house', {
'': ['7 12 16', '0 7 16', '4 7 12'],
'm': ['0 3 7']
})
chord("<Am C D F Am E Am E>")
.dict('house').anchor(66)
.voicing().room(.5)

name: anchor
desc: The top note to align the voicing to. Defaults to c5

params.name: anchorNote
params.description: the note to align the voicing or scale to

name: offset
desc: Sets how the voicing is offset from the anchored position

params.name: shift
params.description: the amount to shift the voicing up or down

examples: chord("<Am C D F Am E Am E>").offset("<0 1 2 3 4 5>") // alter the voicing each time

name: octaves
desc: How many octaves are voicing steps spread apart, defaults to 1
examples: chord("<Am C D F Am E Am E>").octaves("<2 4>").voicing()

name: mode
desc: Remove anchor note from the voicing. Useful for melody harmonization

name: transpose
desc:
Change the pitch of each value by the given amount. Expects numbers or note strings as values.
The amount can be given as a number of semitones or as a string in interval short notation.
If you don't care about enharmonic correctness, just use numbers. Otherwise, pass the interval of
the form: ST where S is the degree number and T the type of interval with

M = major
m = minor
P = perfect
A = augmented
d = diminished

Examples intervals:

1P = unison
3M = major third
3m = minor third
4P = perfect fourth
4A = augmented fourth
5P = perfect fifth
5d = diminished fifth

params.name: amount
params.description: Either number of semitones or interval string.

name: scaleTranspose
desc:
Transposes notes inside the scale by the number of steps.
Expected to be called on a Pattern which already has a {@link Pattern#scale}

params.name: offset
params.description: number of steps inside the scale

name: scale
desc:
Turns numbers into notes in the scale (zero indexed) or quantizes notes to a scale.
When describing notes via numbers, note that negative numbers can be used to wrap backwards
in the scale as well as sharps or flats to produce notes outside of the scale.
Also sets scale for other scale operations, like {@link Pattern#scaleTranspose}.
A scale consists of a root note (e.g. c4, c, f#, bb4) followed by semicolon (':') and then a scale type.
The scale name must be written without spaces (because it would be interpreted as a multi-step pattern otherwise).
If your scale name includes spaces, replace them with colons.
The root note defaults to octave 3, if no octave number is given.

name: addVoicings
desc: Adds a new custom voicing dictionary.

params.name: dictionary
params.description: maps chord symbol to possible voicings

name: voicings
desc:
DEPRECATED: still works, but it is recommended you use .voicing instead (without s).
Turns chord symbols into voicings, using the smoothest voice leading possible.
Uses chord-voicings package.
examples: stack("<C^7 A7 Dm7 G7>".voicings('lefthand'), "<C3 A2 D3 G2>").note()

name: rootNotes
desc: Maps the chords of the incoming pattern to root notes in the given octave.

name: voicing
desc:
Turns chord symbols into voicings. You can use the following control params:

chord: Note, followed by chord symbol, e.g. C Am G7 Bb^7
dict: voicing dictionary to use, falls back to default dictionary
anchor: the note that is used to align the chord
mode: how the voicing is aligned to the anchor

below: top note <= anchor
duck: top note <= anchor, anchor excluded
above: bottom note >= anchor


offset: whole number that shifts the voicing up or down to the next voicing
n: if set, the voicing is played like a scale. Overshooting numbers will be octaved

All of the above controls are optional, except chord.
If you pass a pattern of strings to voicing, they will be interpreted as chords.

name: tune
desc: Assumes a numerical pattern of EDO steps. Accepts a scale name or list of frequencies (see all available names at the link on the reference). Returns a new pattern with all values mapped to a frequency ratio. Similar to xen.

name: xen
desc: Assumes a numerical pattern of scale steps, and a scale. Scales accepted are all preset scale names of tune, arbitrary edos such as 31edo, or an array of frequency ratios. Assumes scales repeat at octave (2/1). Returns a new pattern with all values mapped to their associated frequency, assuming a base frequency of 220hz.

name: cpm
desc: Plays the pattern at the given cycles per minute.

name: setcpm
desc: Changes the global tempo to the given cycles per minute

name: s
desc:
Select a sound / sample by name. When using mininotation, you can also optionally supply 'n' and 'gain' parameters
separated by ':'.

params.name: sound
params.description: The sound / pattern of sounds to pick

name: wt
desc: Position in the wavetable of the wavetable oscillator

params.name: position
params.description: Position in the wavetable from 0 to 1

name: wtenv
desc: Amount of envelope applied wavetable oscillator's position envelope

name: wtattack
desc: Attack time of the wavetable oscillator's position envelope

name: wtdecay
desc: Decay time of the wavetable oscillator's position envelope

name: wtsustain
desc: Sustain time of the wavetable oscillator's position envelope

name: wtrelease
desc: Release time of the wavetable oscillator's position envelope

name: wtrate
desc: Rate of the LFO for the wavetable oscillator's position

name: wtsync
desc: cycle synced rate of the LFO for the wavetable oscillator's position

name: wtdepth
desc: Depth of the LFO for the wavetable oscillator's position

name: wtshape
desc: Shape of the LFO for the wavetable oscillator's position

name: wtdc
desc: DC offset of the LFO for the wavetable oscillator's position

params.name: dcoffset
params.description: dc offset. set to 0 for unipolar

name: wtskew
desc: Skew of the LFO for the wavetable oscillator's position

params.name: skew
params.description: How much to bend the LFO shape

name: warp
desc: Amount of warp (alteration of the waveform) to apply to the wavetable oscillator

params.name: amount
params.description: Warp of the wavetable from 0 to 1

name: warpattack
desc: Attack time of the wavetable oscillator's warp envelope

name: warpdecay
desc: Decay time of the wavetable oscillator's warp envelope

name: warpsustain
desc: Sustain time of the wavetable oscillator's warp envelope

name: warprelease
desc: Release time of the wavetable oscillator's warp envelope

name: warprate
desc: Rate of the LFO for the wavetable oscillator's warp

name: warpdepth
desc: Depth of the LFO for the wavetable oscillator's warp

name: warpshape
desc: Shape of the LFO for the wavetable oscillator's warp

name: warpdc
desc: DC offset of the LFO for the wavetable oscillator's warp

params.name: dcoffset
params.description: dc offset. set to 0 for unipolar

name: warpskew
desc: Skew of the LFO for the wavetable oscillator's warp

params.name: skew
params.description: How much to bend the LFO shape

name: warpmode
desc:
Type of warp (alteration of the waveform) to apply to the wavetable oscillator.
The current options are: none, asym, bendp, bendm, bendmp, sync, quant, fold, pwm, orbit,
spin, chaos, primes, binary, brownian, reciprocal, wormhole, logistic, sigmoid, fractal, flip
examples:
s("morgana").bank("wt_digital").seg(8).note("F1").warp("0 0.25 0.5 0.75 1")
  .warpmode("<asym bendp spin logistic sync wormhole brownian>*2")

name: warpenv
desc: Amount of envelope applied wavetable oscillator's position envelope

name: warpsync
desc: cycle synced rate of the LFO for the wavetable warp position

name: accelerate
desc: A pattern of numbers that speed up (or slow down) samples while they play. Currently only supported by osc / superdirt.

name: velocity
desc: Sets the velocity from 0 to 1. Is multiplied together with gain.

name: gain
desc: Controls the gain by an exponential amount.

name: postgain
desc: Gain applied after all effects have been processed.

name: amp
desc: Like gain, but linear.

name: fmh
desc:
Sets the Frequency Modulation Harmonicity Ratio.
Controls the timbre of the sound.
Whole numbers and simple ratios sound more natural,
while decimal numbers and complex ratios sound metallic.
A number may be added afterwards to control the harmonicity of
any of the 8 individual FMs (e.g. fmh2)
examples:
note("c e g b g e")
.fm(4)
.fmh("<1 2 1.5 1.61>")
._scope()

name: fmenv
desc:
Ramp type of fm envelope. Exp might be a bit broken..
A number may be added afterwards to control the envelope of
any of the 8 individual FMs (e.g. fmenv4)
examples:
note("c e g b g e")
.fm(4)
.fmdecay(.2)
.fmsustain(0)
.fmenv("<exp lin>")
._scope()

name: fmattack
desc:
Attack time for the FM envelope: time it takes to reach maximum modulation
A number may be added afterwards to control the attack of the envelope of
any of the 8 individual FMs (e.g. fmatt5)
examples:
note("c e g b g e")
.fm(4)
.fmattack("<0 .05 .1 .2>")
._scope()

name: fmwave
desc:
Waveform of the fm modulator
A number may be added afterwards to control the waveform
any of the 8 individual FMs (e.g. fmwave6)

name: fmdecay
desc:
Decay time for the FM envelope: seconds until the sustain level is reached after the attack phase.
A number may be added afterwards to control the decay of the envelope of
any of the 8 individual FMs (e.g. fmdec6)
examples:
note("c e g b g e")
.fm(4)
.fmdecay("<.01 .05 .1 .2>")
.fmsustain(.4)
._scope()

name: fmsustain
desc:
Sustain level for the FM envelope: how much modulation is applied after the decay phase
A number may be added afterwards to control the sustain of the envelope of
any of the 8 individual FMs (e.g. fmsus7)
examples:
note("c e g b g e")
.fm(4)
.fmdecay(.1)
.fmsustain("<1 .75 .5 0>")
._scope()

name: fmrelease
desc:
Release time for the FM envelope: how much modulation is applied after the note is released
A number may be added afterwards to control the release of the envelope of
any of the 8 individual FMs (e.g. fmrel8)

name: bank
desc: Select the sound bank to use. To be used together with s. The bank name (+ "_") will be prepended to the value of s.
examples: s("bd sd [~ bd] sd").bank('RolandTR909') // = s("RolandTR909_bd RolandTR909_sd")

name: attack
desc: Amplitude envelope attack time: Specifies how long it takes for the sound to reach its peak value, relative to the onset.

name: decay
desc:
Amplitude envelope decay time: the time it takes after the attack time to reach the sustain level.
Note that the decay is only audible if the sustain value is lower than 1.

name: sustain
desc: Amplitude envelope sustain level: The level which is reached after attack / decay, being sustained until the offset.

name: release
desc: Amplitude envelope release time: The time it takes after the offset to go from sustain level to zero.

name: begin
desc: A pattern of numbers from 0 to 1. Skips the beginning of each sample, e.g. 0.25 to cut off the first quarter from each sample.

params.name: amount
params.description: between 0 and 1, where 1 is the length of the sample

name: end
desc: The same as .begin, but cuts off the end off each sample.

params.name: length
params.description: 1 = whole sample, .5 = half sample, .25 = quarter sample etc..

name: loop
desc:
Loops the sample.
Note that the tempo of the loop is not synced with the cycle tempo.
To change the loop region, use loopBegin / loopEnd.

name: loopBegin
desc:
Begin to loop at a specific point in the sample (inbetween begin and end).
Note that the loop point must be inbetween begin and end, and before loopEnd!
Note: Samples starting with wt_ will automatically loop! (wt = wavetable)

params.name: time
params.description: between 0 and 1, where 1 is the length of the sample

name: loopEnd
desc:
End the looping section at a specific point in the sample (inbetween begin and end).
Note that the loop point must be inbetween begin and end, and after loopBegin!

params.name: time
params.description: between 0 and 1, where 1 is the length of the sample

name: tremolo
desc: Modulate the amplitude of a sound with a continuous waveform

name: tremolosync
desc: Modulate the amplitude of a sound with a continuous waveform

name: tremolodepth
desc: Depth of amplitude modulation

name: tremoloskew
desc: Alter the shape of the modulation waveform

params.name: amount
params.description: between 0 & 1, the shape of the waveform

name: tremolophase
desc: Alter the phase of the modulation waveform

params.name: offset
params.description: the offset in cycles of the modulation

name: tremoloshape
desc: Shape of amplitude modulation
examples: note("{f g c d}%16").tremsync(4).tremoloshape("<sine tri square>").s("sawtooth")

name: drive
desc: Filter overdrive for supported filter types
examples: note("{f g g c d a a#}%16".sub(17)).s("supersaw").lpenv(8).lpf(150).lpq(.8).ftype('ladder').drive("<.5 4>")

name: duckorbit
desc:
Modulate the amplitude of an orbit to create a "sidechain" like effect.
Can be applied to multiple orbits with the ':' mininotation, e.g. duckorbit("2:3")

name: duckdepth
desc:
The amount of ducking applied to target orbit
Can vary across orbits with the ':' mininotation, e.g. duckdepth("0.3:0.1").
Note: this requires first applying the effect to multiple orbits with e.g. duckorbit("2:3").

name: duckonset
desc:
The time required for the ducked signal(s) to reach their lowest volume.
Can be used to prevent clicking or for creative rhythmic effects.
Can vary across orbits with the ':' mininotation, e.g. duckonset("0:0.003").
Note: this requires first applying the effect to multiple orbits with e.g. duckorbit("2:3").
examples:
// Rhythmic
noise: s("pink").distort("2:1").orbit(4) // used rhythmically with 0.3 onset below
hhat: s("hh*16").orbit(7)
ducker: s("bd*4").bank("tr909").duckorbit("4:7").duckonset("0.3:0.003").duckattack(0.25)

name: duckattack
desc:
The time required for the ducked signal(s) to return to their normal volume.
Can vary across orbits with the ':' mininotation, e.g. duckonset("0:0.003").
Note: this requires first applying the effect to multiple orbits with e.g. duckorbit("2:3").

name: byteBeatExpression
desc: Create byte beats with custom expressions

name: byteBeatStartTime
desc: Create byte beats with custom expressions

name: pw
desc: Controls the pulsewidth of the pulse oscillator

name: pwrate
desc: Controls the lfo rate for the pulsewidth of the pulse oscillator

name: pwsweep
desc: Controls the lfo sweep for the pulsewidth of the pulse oscillator

name: channel
desc: Choose the channel the pattern is sent to

name: cut
desc: In the style of classic drum-machines, cut will stop a playing sample as soon as another samples with in same cutgroup is to be played. An example would be an open hi-hat followed by a closed one, essentially muting the open.

name: lpenv
desc: Sets the lowpass filter envelope modulation depth.

params.name: modulation
params.description: depth of the lowpass filter envelope between 0 and n

name: hpenv
desc: Sets the highpass filter envelope modulation depth.

params.name: modulation
params.description: depth of the highpass filter envelope between 0 and n

name: bpenv
desc: Sets the bandpass filter envelope modulation depth.

params.name: modulation
params.description: depth of the bandpass filter envelope between 0 and n

name: lpattack
desc: Sets the attack duration for the lowpass filter envelope.

name: hpattack
desc: Sets the attack duration for the highpass filter envelope.

params.name: attack
params.description: time of the highpass filter envelope

name: bpattack
desc: Sets the attack duration for the bandpass filter envelope.

params.name: attack
params.description: time of the bandpass filter envelope

name: lpdecay
desc: Sets the decay duration for the lowpass filter envelope.

name: hpdecay
desc: Sets the decay duration for the highpass filter envelope.

params.name: decay
params.description: time of the highpass filter envelope

name: bpdecay
desc: Sets the decay duration for the bandpass filter envelope.

params.name: decay
params.description: time of the bandpass filter envelope

name: lpsustain
desc: Sets the sustain amplitude for the lowpass filter envelope.

params.name: sustain
params.description: amplitude of the lowpass filter envelope

name: hpsustain
desc: Sets the sustain amplitude for the highpass filter envelope.

params.name: sustain
params.description: amplitude of the highpass filter envelope

name: bpsustain
desc: Sets the sustain amplitude for the bandpass filter envelope.

params.name: sustain
params.description: amplitude of the bandpass filter envelope

name: lprelease
desc: Sets the release time for the lowpass filter envelope.

name: hprelease
desc: Sets the release time for the highpass filter envelope.

params.name: release
params.description: time of the highpass filter envelope

name: bprelease
desc: Sets the release time for the bandpass filter envelope.

params.name: release
params.description: time of the bandpass filter envelope

name: ftype
desc: Sets the filter type. The ladder filter is more aggressive. More types might be added in the future.
examples: note("{f g g c d a a#}%8").s("sawtooth").lpenv(4).lpf(500).ftype("<0 1 2>").lpq(1)

note("c f g g a c d4").fast(2)
.sound('sawtooth')
.lpf(200).fanchor(0)
.lpenv(3).lpq(1)
.ftype("<ladder 12db 24db>")

name: fanchor
desc: controls the center of the filter envelope. 0 is unipolar positive, .5 is bipolar, 1 is unipolar negative
examples:
note("{f g g c d a a#}%8").s("sawtooth").lpf("{1000}%2")
.lpenv(8).fanchor("<0 .5 1>")

name: lprate
desc: Rate of the LFO for the lowpass filter

name: lpsync
desc: Cycle-synced rate of the LFO for the lowpass filter

name: lpdepth
desc: Depth of the LFO for the lowpass filter

name: lpdepthfrequency
desc: Depth of the LFO for the lowpass filter, in HZ

name: lpshape
desc: Shape of the LFO for the lowpass filter

name: lpdc
desc: DC offset of the LFO for the lowpass filter

params.name: dcoffset
params.description: dc offset. set to 0 for unipolar

name: lpskew
desc: Skew of the LFO for the lowpass filter

params.name: skew
params.description: How much to bend the LFO shape

name: bprate
desc: Rate of the LFO for the bandpass filter

name: bpsync
desc: Cycle-synced rate of the LFO for the bandpass filter

name: bpdepth
desc: Depth of the LFO for the bandpass filter

name: bpdepthfrequency
desc: Depth of the LFO for the bandpass filter, in HZ

name: bpshape
desc: Shape of the LFO for the bandpass filter

name: bpdc
desc: DC offset of the LFO for the bandpass filter

params.name: dcoffset
params.description: dc offset. set to 0 for unipolar

name: bpskew
desc: Skew of the LFO for the bandpass filter

params.name: skew
params.description: How much to bend the LFO shape

name: hprate
desc: Rate of the LFO for the highpass filter

name: hpsync
desc: Cycle-synced rate of the LFO for the highpass filter

name: hpdepth
desc: Depth of the LFO for the highpass filter

name: hpdepthfrequency
desc: Depth of the LFO for the hipass filter, in hz

name: hpshape
desc: Shape of the LFO for the highpass filter

name: hpdc
desc: DC offset of the LFO for the highpass filter

params.name: dcoffset
params.description: dc offset. set to 0 for unipolar

name: hpskew
desc: Skew of the LFO for the highpass filter

params.name: skew
params.description: How much to bend the LFO shape

name: vib
desc: Applies a vibrato to the frequency of the oscillator.
examples:
// change the modulation depth with ":"
note("a e")
.vib("<.5 1 2 4 8 16>:12")
._scope()

name: noise
desc: Adds pink noise to the mix

name: vibmod
desc: Sets the vibrato depth in semitones. Only has an effect if vibrato | vib | v is is also set
examples:
// change the vibrato frequency with ":"
note("a e")
.vibmod("<.25 .5 1 2 12>:8")
._scope()

name: djf
desc: DJ filter, below 0.5 is low pass filter, above is high pass filter.

params.name: cutoff
params.description: below 0.5 is low pass filter, above is high pass filter

name: lock
desc: Specifies whether delaytime is calculated relative to cps.

params.name: enable
params.description: When set to 1, delaytime is a direct multiple of a cycle.

name: detune
desc: Set detune for stacked voices of supported oscillators.
examples: note("d f a a# a d3").fast(2).s("supersaw").detune("<.1 .2 .5 24.1>")

name: unison
desc: Set number of stacked voices for supported oscillators.
examples: note("d f a a# a d3").fast(2).s("supersaw").unison("<1 2 7>")

name: spread
desc: Set the stereo pan spread for supported oscillators
examples: note("d f a a# a d3").fast(2).s("supersaw").spread("<0 .3 1>")

name: dry
desc: Set dryness of reverb. See room and size for more information about reverb.

name: fadeTime
desc: Used when using begin/end or chop/striate and friends, to change the fade out time of the 'grain' envelope.

name: freq
desc: Set frequency of sound.

params.name: frequency
params.description: in Hz. the audible range is between 20 and 20000 Hz

name: pattack
desc: Attack time of pitch envelope.

name: pdecay
desc: Decay time of pitch envelope.

name: prelease
desc: Release time of pitch envelope
examples:
note("<c eb g bb> ~")
.release(.5) // to hear the pitch release
.prelease("<0 .1 .25 .5>")

name: penv
desc:
Amount of pitch envelope. Negative values will flip the envelope.
If you don't set other pitch envelope controls, pattack:.2 will be the default.

name: pcurve
desc: Curve of envelope. Defaults to linear. exponential is good for kicks

name: panchor
desc:
Sets the range anchor of the envelope:

anchor 0: range = [note, note + penv]
anchor 1: range = [note - penv, note]
If you don't set an anchor, the value will default to the psustain value.

name: leslie
desc: Emulation of a Leslie speaker: speakers rotating in a wooden amplified cabinet.

name: lrate
desc: Rate of modulation / rotation for leslie effect

name: lsize
desc: Physical size of the cabinet in meters. Be careful, it might be slightly larger than your computer. Affects the Doppler amount (pitch warble)

name: octave
desc: Sets the default octave of a synth.

name: orbit
desc: An orbit is a global parameter context for patterns. Patterns with the same orbit will share the same global effects.

name: bus
desc:
A bus is a send which can be used for mixing patterns. It combines with..
s("bus") to play that bus through another pattern (for, say, applying non-linear
effects like distortion to multiple signals)
otherPat.bmod(..) (to modulate another pattern with the bus)

name: busgain
desc: Postgain multiplier prior to sending the signal to the audio bus.

name: pan
desc: Sets position in stereo.

params.name: pan
params.description: between 0 and 1, from left to right (assuming stereo), once round a circle (assuming multichannel)

examples: s("bd rim sd rim bd ~ cp rim").pan(sine.slow(2))

name: panspan
desc: Controls how much multichannel output is fanned out

params.name: span
params.description: between -inf and inf, negative is backwards ordering

name: pansplay
desc: Controls how much multichannel output is spread

name: roomsize
desc:
Sets the room size of the reverb, see room.
When this property is changed, the reverb will be recaculated, so only change this sparsely..

name: distortvol
desc: Postgain for waveshaping distortion.

name: compressor
desc:
Dynamics Compressor. The params are compressor("threshold:ratio:knee:attack:release")
More info here

name: speed
desc: Changes the speed of sample playback, i.e. a cheap way of changing pitch.

params.name: speed
params.description: inf to inf, negative numbers play the sample backwards.

name: stretch
desc: Changes the speed of sample playback, i.e. a cheap way of changing pitch.

params.name: factor
params.description: inf to inf, negative numbers play the sample backwards.

name: unit
desc: Used in conjunction with speed, accepts values of "r" (rate, default behavior), "c" (cycles), or "s" (seconds). Using unit "c" means speed will be interpreted in units of cycles, e.g. speed "1" means samples will be stretched to fill a cycle. Using unit "s" means the playback speed will be adjusted so that the duration is the number of seconds specified by speed.

name: squiz
desc:
Made by Calum Gunn. Reminiscent of some weird mixture of filter, ring-modulator and pitch-shifter. The SuperCollider manual defines Squiz as:
"A simplistic pitch-raising algorithm. It's not meant to sound natural; its sound is reminiscent of some weird mixture of filter, ring-modulator and pitch-shifter, depending on the input. The algorithm works by cutting the signal into fragments (delimited by upwards-going zero-crossings) and squeezing those fragments in the time domain (i.e. simply playing them back faster than they came in), leaving silences inbetween. All the parameters apart from memlen can be modulated."

params.name: squiz
params.description: Try passing multiples of 2 to it - 2, 4, 8 etc.

name: vowel
desc: Formant filter to make things sound like vowels.

params.name: vowel
params.description: You can use a e i o u ae aa oe ue y uh un en an on, corresponding to [a] [e] [i] [o] [u] [] [] [] [y] [] [] [] [] [] []. Aliases: aa =  = , oe =  = , y = , ae = .

examples: s("bd sd mt ht bd [~ cp] ht lt").vowel("[a|e|i|o|u]")

name: density
desc: crackle noise density

name: clip
desc: Multiplies the duration with the given number. Also cuts samples off at the end if they exceed the duration.

name: duration
desc: Sets the duration of the event in cycles. Similar to clip / legato, it also cuts samples off at the end if they exceed the duration.

name: transient
desc:
Transient shaper. Gives independent control over the emphasis on transients
and sustains

params.name: sustain
params.description: Emphasis on the sustains; between -1 (deaccentuate) and 1 (accentuate)

name: wtphaserand
desc: Amount of randomness of the initial phase of the wavetable oscillator.

params.name: amount
params.description: Randomness of the initial phase. Between 0 (not random) and 1 (fully random)

name: chorus
desc: mix control for the chorus effect

name: crush
desc: Bit crusher effect.

params.name: depth
params.description: between 1 (for drastic reduction in bit-depth) to 16 (for barely no reduction).

name: coarse
desc: Fake-resampling for lowering the sample rate. Caution: This effect seems to only work in chromium based browsers

params.name: factor
params.description: 1 for original 2 for half, 3 for a third and so on.

name: phaser
desc: Phaser audio effect that approximates popular guitar pedals.

name: phasersweep
desc: The frequency sweep range of the lfo for the phaser effect. Defaults to 2000

params.name: phasersweep
params.description: most useful values are between 0 and 4000

name: phasercenter
desc: The center frequency of the phaser in HZ. Defaults to 1000

name: phaserdepth
desc: The amount the signal is affected by the phaser effect. Defaults to 0.75

name: delay
desc:
Sets the level of the delay signal.
When using mininotation, you can also optionally add the 'delaytime' and 'delayfeedback' parameter,
separated by ':'.

name: delayfeedback
desc:
Sets the level of the signal that is fed back into the delay.
Caution: Values >= 1 will result in a signal that gets louder and louder! Don't do it

name: delayspeed
desc: Sets the time of the delay effect.

params.name: delayspeed
params.description: controls the pitch of the delay feedback

name: delaysync
desc: Sets the time of the delay effect in cycles.

name: room
desc:
Sets the level of reverb.
When using mininotation, you can also optionally add the 'size' parameter, separated by ':'.

name: roomlp
desc:
Reverb lowpass starting frequency (in hertz).
When this property is changed, the reverb will be recaculated, so only change this sparsely..

name: roomdim
desc:
Reverb lowpass frequency at -60dB (in hertz).
When this property is changed, the reverb will be recaculated, so only change this sparsely..

name: roomfade
desc:
Reverb fade time (in seconds).
When this property is changed, the reverb will be recaculated, so only change this sparsely..

name: irspeed
desc: Sets speed of the sample for the impulse response.

name: irbegin
desc: Sets the beginning of the IR response sample

name: shape
desc:
(Deprecated) Wave shaping distortion. WARNING: can suddenly get unpredictably loud.
Please use distort instead, which has a more predictable response curve
second option in optional array syntax (ex: ".9:.5") applies a postgain to the output

name: distort
desc:
Wave shaping distortion. CAUTION: it can get loud.
Second option in optional array syntax (ex: ".9:.5") applies a postgain to the output. Third option sets the waveshaping type.
Most useful values are usually between 0 and 10 (depending on source gain). If you are feeling adventurous, you can turn it up to 11 and beyond ;)

name: distorttype
desc: Type of waveshaping distortion to apply.
examples:
s("sine").note("F1*2").release(1)
  .penv(24).pdecay(0.05)
  .distort(rand.range(1, 8))
  .distorttype("<fold chebyshev scurve diode asym sinefold>")

name: soft
desc: Soft-clipping distortion

name: hard
desc: Hard-clipping distortion

name: cubic
desc: Cubic polynomial distortion

name: diode
desc: Diode-emulating distortion

name: asym
desc: Asymmetrical diode distortion

name: fold
desc: Wavefolding distortion

name: sinefold
desc: Wavefolding distortion composed with sinusoid

name: chebyshev
desc: Distortion via Chebyshev polynomials

name: markcss
desc: Overrides the css of highlighted events. Make sure to use single quotes!

name: slider
desc: Displays a slider widget to allow the user manipulate a value

name: label
desc: Sets the displayed text for an event on the pianoroll

name: color
desc: Sets the color of the hap in visualizations like pianoroll or highlighting.

name: drawLine
desc:
Intended for a debugging, drawLine renders the pattern as a string, where each character represents the same time span.
Should only be used with single characters as values, otherwise the character slots will be messed up.
Character legend:

"|" cycle separator
"-" hold previous value
"." silence

name: log
desc: Writes the content of the current event to the console (visible in the side menu).

name: logValues
desc:
A simplified version of log which writes all "values" (various configurable parameters)
within the event to the console (visible in the side menu).

name: pianoroll
desc:
Visualises a pattern as a scrolling 'pianoroll', displayed in the background of the editor. To show a pianoroll for all running patterns, use all(pianoroll). To have a pianoroll appear below
a pattern instead, prefix with _, e.g.: sound("bd sd")._pianoroll().

params.name: options
params.description: Object containing all the optional following parameters as key value pairs:

params.name: cycles
params.description: number of cycles to be displayed at the same time - defaults to 4

params.name: playhead
params.description: location of the active notes on the time axis - 0 to 1, defaults to 0.5

params.name: vertical
params.description: displays the roll vertically - 0 by default

params.name: labels
params.description: displays labels on individual notes (see the label function) - 0 by default

params.name: flipTime
params.description: reverse the direction of the roll - 0 by default

params.name: flipValues
params.description: reverse the relative location of notes on the value axis - 0 by default

params.name: overscan
params.description: lookup X cycles outside of the cycles window to display notes in advance - 1 by default

params.name: hideNegative
params.description: hide notes with negative time (before starting playing the pattern) - 0 by default

params.name: smear
params.description: notes leave a solid trace - 0 by default

params.name: fold
params.description: notes takes the full value axis width - 0 by default

params.name: active
params.description: hexadecimal or CSS color of the active notes - defaults to #FFCA28

params.name: inactive
params.description: hexadecimal or CSS color of the inactive notes - defaults to #7491D2

params.name: background
params.description: hexadecimal or CSS color of the background - defaults to transparent

params.name: playheadColor
params.description: hexadecimal or CSS color of the line representing the play head - defaults to white

params.name: fill
params.description: notes are filled with color (otherwise only the label is displayed) - 0 by default

params.name: fillActive
params.description: active notes are filled with color - 0 by default

params.name: stroke
params.description: notes are shown with colored borders - 0 by default

params.name: strokeActive
params.description: active notes are shown with colored borders - 0 by default

params.name: hideInactive
params.description: only active notes are shown - 0 by default

params.name: colorizeInactive
params.description: use note color for inactive notes - 1 by default

params.name: fontFamily
params.description: define the font used by notes labels - defaults to 'monospace'

params.name: minMidi
params.description: minimum note value to display on the value axis - defaults to 10

params.name: maxMidi
params.description: maximum note value to display on the value axis - defaults to 90

params.name: autorange
params.description: automatically calculate the minMidi and maxMidi parameters - 0 by default

name: wordfall
desc:
Displays a vertical pianoroll with event labels.
Supports all the same options as pianoroll.

name: pitchwheel
desc: Renders a pitch circle to visualize frequencies within one octave

name: spiral
desc: Displays a spiral visual.

params.name: options
params.description: Object containing all the optional following parameters as key value pairs:

params.name: stretch
params.description: controls the rotations per cycle ratio, where 1 = 1 cycle / 360 degrees

params.name: cap
params.description: style of line ends: butt (default), round, square

params.name: inset
params.description: number of rotations before spiral starts (default 3)

params.name: playheadColor
params.description: color of playhead, defaults to white

params.name: playheadLength
params.description: length of playhead in rotations, defaults to 0.02

params.name: playheadThickness
params.description: thickness of playheadrotations, defaults to thickness

params.name: steady
params.description: steadyness of spiral vs playhead. 1 = spiral doesn't move, playhead does.

params.name: activeColor
params.description: color of active segment. defaults to foreground of theme

params.name: inactiveColor
params.description: color of inactive segments. defaults to gutterForeground of theme

params.name: colorizeInactive
params.description: wether or not to colorize inactive segments, defaults to 0

params.name: fade
params.description: wether or not past and future should fade out. defaults to 1

params.name: logSpiral
params.description: wether or not the spiral should be logarithmic. defaults to 0

name: fscope
desc: Renders an oscilloscope for the frequency domain of the audio signal.

params.name: color
params.description: line color as hex or color name. defaults to white.

params.name: pos
params.description: y-position relative to screen height. 0 = top, 1 = bottom of screen

params.name: lean
params.description: y-axis alignment where 0 = top and 1 = bottom

name: scope
desc: Renders an oscilloscope for the time domain of the audio signal.

params.name: align
params.description: if 1, the scope will be aligned to the first zero crossing. defaults to 1

params.name: color
params.description: line color as hex or color name. defaults to white.

params.name: pos
params.description: y-position relative to screen height. 0 = top, 1 = bottom of screen

params.name: trigger
params.description: amplitude value that is used to align the scope. defaults to 0.

name: spectrum
desc: Renders a spectrum analyzer for the incoming audio signal.

name: source
desc: Define a custom webaudio node to use as a sound source.

name: channels
desc: Allows you to set the output channels on the interface

name: midichan
desc: MIDI channel: Sets the MIDI channel for the event.

name: midiport
desc: MIDI port: Sets the MIDI port for the event.

name: midicmd
desc: MIDI command: Sends a MIDI command message.

name: control
desc: MIDI control: Sends a MIDI control change message.

name: ccn
desc: MIDI control number: Sends a MIDI control change message.

name: ccv
desc: MIDI control value: Sends a MIDI control change message.

name: nrpnn
desc: MIDI NRPN non-registered parameter number: Sends a MIDI NRPN non-registered parameter number message.

name: nrpv
desc: MIDI NRPN non-registered parameter value: Sends a MIDI NRPN non-registered parameter value message.

name: progNum
desc: MIDI program number: Sends a MIDI program change message.

name: sysex
desc: MIDI sysex: Sends a MIDI sysex message.

name: sysexid
desc: MIDI sysex ID: Sends a MIDI sysex identifier message.

name: sysexdata
desc: MIDI sysex data: Sends a MIDI sysex message.

name: midibend
desc: MIDI pitch bend: Sends a MIDI pitch bend message.

name: miditouch
desc: MIDI key after touch: Sends a MIDI key after touch message.

name: oschost
desc: The host to send open sound control messages to. Requires running the OSC bridge.

name: oscport
desc: The port to send open sound control messages to. Requires running the OSC bridge.

name: onTriggerTime
desc:
make something happen on event time
uses browser timeout which is innacurate for audio tasks

name: mousex
desc: The mouse's x position value ranges from 0 to 1.

name: mousey
desc: The mouse's y position value ranges from 0 to 1.

name: whenKey
desc:
Do something on a keypress, or array of keypresses
Key name reference

name: keyDown
desc:
returns true when a key or array of keys is held
Key name reference

name: csoundm
desc:
Sends notes to Csound for rendering with MIDI semantics. The hap value is
translated to these Csound pfields:
p1 -- Csound instrument either as a number (1-based, can be a fraction),
or as a string name.
p2 -- time in beats (usually seconds) from start of performance.
p3 -- duration in beats (usually seconds).
p4 -- MIDI key number (as a real number, not an integer but in [0, 127].
p5 -- MIDI velocity (as a real number, not an integer but in [0, 127].
p6 -- Strudel controls, as a string.

name: defaultmidimap
desc: configures the default midimap, which is used when no "midimap" port is set

name: midimaps
desc: Adds midimaps to the registry. Inside each midimap, control names (e.g. lpf) are mapped to cc numbers.
examples:
midimaps({ mymap: { lpf: 74 } })
$: note("c a f e")
.lpf(sine.slow(4))
.midimap('mymap')
.midi()

name: midi
desc: MIDI output: Opens a MIDI output port.

params.name: midiport
params.description: MIDI device name or index defaulting to 0

examples: note("c4").midichan(1).midi('IAC Driver Bus 1', { controller: true, latency: 50 })

name: _initialize
desc: Initialize a midi device

name: midin
desc:
MIDI input: Opens a MIDI input port to receive MIDI control change messages.
The output is a function that accepts a midi cc value to query as well as (optionally) a midi channel

params.name: input
params.description: MIDI device name or index defaulting to 0

examples:
const cc = await midin('IAC Driver Bus 1')
note("c a f e").lpf(cc(0).range(0, 1000)).lpq(cc(1).range(0, 10)).sound("sawtooth")

const allCC = await midin('IAC Driver Bus 1')
const cc = (ccNum) => allCC(ccNum, 2) // just channel 2
note("c a f e").s("saw")
  .when(cc(0).gt(0), x => x.postgain(0))

name: midikeys
desc:
MIDI keyboard: Opens a MIDI input port to receive MIDI keyboard messages.
The note length is fixed as Superdough is not currently set up for undetermined
note durations

params.name: input
params.description: MIDI device name or index defaulting to 0

examples:
const kb = await midikeys('Arturia KeyStep 32')
kb("0.5 1")
  .s("saw")
  .add(note(rand.mul(0.3)))
  .lpf(1000).lpe(2).room(0.5)

name: accelerationX
desc: The accelerometer's x-axis value ranges from 0 to 1.

name: accelerationY
desc: The accelerometer's y-axis value ranges from 0 to 1.

name: accelerationZ
desc: The accelerometer's z-axis value ranges from 0 to 1.

name: gravityX
desc: The device's gravity x-axis value ranges from 0 to 1.

name: gravityY
desc: The device's gravity y-axis value ranges from 0 to 1.

name: gravityZ
desc: The device's gravity z-axis value ranges from 0 to 1.

name: rotationAlpha
desc: The device's rotation around the alpha-axis value ranges from 0 to 1.

name: rotationBeta
desc: The device's rotation around the beta-axis value ranges from 0 to 1.

name: rotationGamma
desc: The device's rotation around the gamma-axis value ranges from 0 to 1.

name: orientationAlpha
desc: The device's orientation alpha value ranges from 0 to 1.

name: orientationBeta
desc: The device's orientation beta value ranges from 0 to 1.

name: orientationGamma
desc: The device's orientation gamma value ranges from 0 to 1.

name: absoluteOrientationAlpha
desc: The device's absolute orientation alpha value ranges from 0 to 1.

name: absoluteOrientationBeta
desc: The device's absolute orientation beta value ranges from 0 to 1.

name: absoluteOrientationGamma
desc: The device's absolute orientation gamma value ranges from 0 to 1.

name: osc
desc:
Sends each hap as an OSC message, which can be picked up by SuperCollider or any other OSC-enabled software.
For more info, read MIDI & OSC in the docs

name: fmi
desc:
Sets the Frequency Modulation of the synth.
Controls the modulation index, which defines the brightness of the sound.
A number may be added afterwards to control the modulation index of
any of the 8 individual FMs (e.g. fm3). Also, FMs may be routed into
each other with matrix commands like fm13, which would send fm1 back into
fm3
examples:
note("c e g b g e")
.fm("<0 1 2 8 32>")
._scope()

name: bpf
desc:
Sets the center frequency of the band-pass filter. When using mininotation, you
can also optionally supply the 'bpq' parameter separated by ':'.

name: bpq
desc: Sets the band-pass q-factor (resonance).

name: lpf
desc:
Applies the cutoff frequency of the low-pass filter.
When using mininotation, you can also optionally add the 'lpq' parameter, separated by ':'.

name: hpf
desc:
Applies the cutoff frequency of the high-pass filter.
When using mininotation, you can also optionally add the 'hpq' parameter, separated by ':'.

name: hpq
desc: Controls the high-pass q-value.

name: lpq
desc: Controls the low-pass q-value.

name: iresponse
desc: Sets the sample to use as an impulse response for the reverb.

params.name: sample
params.description: to use as an impulse response

name: adsr
desc: ADSR envelope: Combination of Attack, Decay, Sustain, and Release.

name: lfo
desc:
Configures an LFO. Can be called in sequence like pat.lfo(...).lfo(...) to set up multiple LFOs.
There are two ways to declare which control will be modulated:

Explicitly put control in the config (e.g. lfo({ c: "lpf" }))
If the control parameter is absent, the control immediately before the lfo call will be used
(e.g. s("saw").lpf(500).lfo() to modulate lpf)

Modulators can be referred to by id so that they can be updated later e.g. inside
a sometimes. See example below.

params.name: config.subControl
params.description: Sub-control name to append to the control key. Aliases: sc

params.name: config.depth
params.description: Relative modulation depth. Aliases: dep, dr

params.name: config.dcoffset
params.description: DC offset / bias for the waveform. Aliases: dc

params.name: config.retrig
params.description: If > 0.5, the LFO will retrigger on each event. Aliases: rt

params.name: id
params.description: ID to use for this modulator

name: env
desc:
Configures an envelope. Can be called in sequence like pat.env(...).env(...) to set up multiple envelopes
There are two ways to declare which control will be modulated:

Explicitly put control in the config (e.g. env({ c: "lpf" }))
If the control parameter is absent, the control immediately before the env call will be used
(e.g. s("saw").lpf(500).env({ a: 1 }) to modulate lpf)

Modulators can be referred to by id so that they can be updated later e.g. inside
a sometimes. See example below.

params.name: config.subControl
params.description: Sub-control name to append to the control key. Aliases: sc

params.name: config.depth
params.description: Relative modulation depth. Aliases: dep, dr

params.name: config.attack
params.description: Time to reach depth. Aliases: att, a

params.name: config.decay
params.description: Time to reach sustain. Aliases: dec, d

params.name: config.release
params.description: Time to return to nominal value. Aliases: rel, r

params.name: config.acurve
params.description: Snappiness of attack curve (-1 = relaxed, 1 = snappy). Aliases: ac

params.name: config.dcurve
params.description: Snappiness of decay curve (-1 = relaxed, 1 = snappy). Aliases: dc

params.name: config.rcurve
params.description: Snappiness of release curve (-1 = relaxed, 1 = snappy). Aliases: rc

params.name: id
params.description: ID to use for this modulator

examples:
s("pulse").lpf(500).env({ a: 1 })
  .env({ c: "s", a: 1 })
  .diode(0.3)
  .sometimes(x => x.env({ a: "0.5" }, 1)) // envelope #1 (0-indexed)

s("pulse").lpf(500).env({ a: 1 }, 'lpf_mod')
  .env({ c: "s", a: 1 })
  .diode(0.3)
  .sometimes(x => x.env({ a: "0.5" }, 'lpf_mod'))

name: bmod
desc:
Modulates with the output from a given bus.
Can be called in sequence like pat.bmod(...).bmod(...) to set up multiple modulators
Send to an audio bus with otherPat.bus(..).
There are two ways to declare which control will be modulated:

Explicitly put control in the config (e.g. bmod({ id: 2, c: "lpf" }))
If the control parameter is absent, the control immediately before the bmod call will be used
(e.g. s("saw").lpf(500).bmod({ id: 2 }) to modulate lpf)

Modulators can be referred to by id so that they can be updated later e.g. inside
a sometimes. See example below.

params.name: config.bus
params.description: Bus to get modulation signal from

params.name: config.subControl
params.description: Sub-control name to append to the control key. Aliases: sc

params.name: config.depth
params.description: Relative modulation depth. Aliases: dep, dr

params.name: id
params.description: ID to use for this modulator

name: _euclidRot
examples:
// A thirteenth-century Persian rhythm called Khafif-e-ramal.
note("c3").euclid(2,5)

// The archetypal pattern of the Cumbia from Colombia, as well as a Calypso rhythm from Trinidad.
note("c3").euclid(3,4)

// Another thirteenth century Persian rhythm by the name of Khafif-e-ramal, as well as a Rumanian folk-dance rhythm.
note("c3").euclidRot(3,5,2)

// A Ruchenitza rhythm used in a Bulgarian folk dance.
note("c3").euclid(3,7)

// Another Ruchenitza Bulgarian folk-dance rhythm.
note("c3").euclid(4,7)

// The Aksak rhythm of Turkey.
note("c3").euclid(4,9)

// The metric pattern used by Frank Zappa in his piece titled Outside Now.
note("c3").euclid(4,11)

// Yields the York-Samai pattern, a popular Arab rhythm.
note("c3").euclid(5,6)

// The Nawakhat pattern, another popular Arab rhythm.
note("c3").euclid(5,7)

// A popular Arab rhythm called Agsag-Samai.
note("c3").euclid(5,9)

// The metric pattern used by Moussorgsky in Pictures at an Exhibition.
note("c3").euclid(5,11)

// The Venda clapping pattern of a South African childrens song.
note("c3").euclid(5,12)

// The Bossa-Nova rhythm necklace of Brazil.
note("c3").euclid(5,16)

// A typical rhythm played on the Bendir (frame drum).
note("c3").euclid(7,8)

// A common West African bell pattern.
note("c3").euclid(7,12)

// A Samba rhythm necklace from Brazil.
note("c3").euclidRot(7,16,14)

// A rhythm necklace used in the Central African Republic.
note("c3").euclid(9,16)

// A rhythm necklace of the Aka Pygmies of Central Africa.
note("c3").euclidRot(11,24,14)

// Another rhythm necklace of the Aka Pygmies of the upper Sangha.
note("c3").euclidRot(13,24,5)

name: clearScope
desc:
Clears all user-defined variables and functions from the scope.
This removes variables created during block-based evaluation.

name: Pattern
desc: Create a pattern. As an end user, you will most likely not create a Pattern directly.

params.name: query
params.description: The function that maps a State to an array of Hap.

name: fmap
desc: see withValue

name: queryArc
